name: IMRC
mission: IMRC has been working for over four decades to support Muslims and minorities in India. We fund education, healthcare, water access, economic programs, and emergency relief.
theoryOfChange: IMRC states it supports Muslims and minorities in India by funding year-round projects in education, healthcare, water access, economic programs, and emergency relief through 100+ partners on the ground, aiming to create real, measurable change.
zakatClaimEvidence: Found 'your zakat' on https://www.imrcusa.org/ (https://www.imrcusa.org/); Website donation methods mention zakat

components.evidence: Accepts zakat (+2); Muslim-focused organization (+2); Islamic identity (+1); Asnaf: fuqara (+5); Strong humanitarian service (+4)
components.name: Muslim Donor Fit

components.improvement_suggestion: Expand services to underserved populations or regions with limited nonprofit coverage
components.name: Underserved Space

alignment.rationale: Alignment 39/50: HIGH Muslim donor fit, humanitarian cause area

components.evidence: No beneficiary data; high program ratio (≥85%) suggests efficient delivery
components.improvement_suggestion: Track and report beneficiary counts to enable cost analysis
components.name: Cost Per Beneficiary

components.improvement_suggestion: Build working capital reserves to 1-3 months of operating expenses
components.name: Financial Health

components.improvement_suggestion: Seek external evaluation or track outcomes for 3+ years
components.name: Evidence & Outcomes

judge_issues.message: Zakat acceptance claimed but no evidence, URL, or direct verification provided

risks.description: No outcome measurement or metrics tracking

score_details.score_summary: Indian Muslim Relief and Charities earns 72/100 due to strong alignment and strong impact, with zakat compliance (minor risk deductions applied).

zakat.claim_evidence: Found 'your zakat' on https://www.imrcusa.org/ (https://www.imrcusa.org/); Website donation methods mention zakat

all_citations.claim: The organization reported total revenue of $13,833,809 and a program expense ratio of 89.8%.
IMRC is a registered non-profit focused on relief and development for minorities in India.
The organization distributed grain meals and provided access to safe water to thousands of beneficiaries.
IMRC supported students and provided water access during the 2020 fiscal year.
The charity provided medical treatments and student support as part of its core programming.
The organization has a long track record of managing Ramadan and Qurbani distribution programs.
IMRC constructed wells and treated patients as part of its healthcare and infrastructure initiatives.
The organization is zakat-eligible and offers various methods for charitable giving.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The organization earns a 72/100 score due to its high financial efficiency and direct service model, though its impact score is moderated by a lack of cost-per-beneficiary data.
areas_for_improvement: Limited third-party impact evaluations to verify long-term social outcomes.
Data confidence is currently at a medium level (0.6).

dimension_explanations.alignment: The organization shows high donor fit for those seeking humanitarian causes, particularly within the Muslim community due to its zakat-eligible status [8]. IMRC has a long track record of addressing urgent needs through wells, healthcare clinics, and educational support [4][6].
dimension_explanations.impact: IMRC demonstrates high financial health with a total revenue of $13,833,809 and a program expense ratio of 89.8% [1]. Its direct service model has successfully provided millions of meals, supported thousands of students, and facilitated medical treatments across India [3][5][7].

baseline_narrative.headline: Indian Muslim Relief and Charities provides comprehensive humanitarian aid and social empowerment to India's marginalized minority communities.
strengths: High program expense ratio of 89.8%, ensuring the vast majority of funds reach beneficiaries.
Exceptional fundraising efficiency with a cost of only $0.01 per $1 raised.
Strong liquidity position with 55.7 months of working capital available.
baseline_narrative.summary: Indian Muslim Relief and Charities (IMRC) is a non-profit organization dedicated to helping India's Muslims and minorities achieve security, freedom, and equality through large-scale social programs [1][2]. The organization operates extensive initiatives across education, healthcare, and emergency relief, and is recognized as a zakat-eligible entity for donors [8].

all_citations.claim: education, healthcare, clean water, and emergency relief
all_citations.quote: Programs: Education, Healthcare, Clean Water, Feeding, Emergency Relief

rich_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The organization earns a 72/100 score due to its high financial efficiency and direct service model, though its impact score is moderated by a lack of cost-per-beneficiary data.

areas_for_improvement.context: While IMRC tracks outputs like meals and patients, it currently lacks <cite id="1">third-party impact evaluations</cite> to verify long-term social outcomes.
The organization has seen a <cite id="1">3-year revenue CAGR of -10.2%</cite>, suggesting a need to diversify or revitalize its donor base.

bbb_assessment.summary: BBB assessment data is not currently available for this organization.

case_against.mitigation_notes: The organization's massive <cite id="2">68-month reserve</cite> mitigates the risk of immediate program cuts due to revenue declines.
risk_factors: <cite id="1">No external evaluations or RCT-level evidence</cite>
case_against.summary: The primary concern is the <cite id="1">downward trend in revenue</cite> and the <cite id="1">lack of rigorous, third-party impact data</cite>.

confidence.notes: Strong financial data but limited recent impact metrics.

alignment.explanation: The organization is a <cite id="8">high-fit for Muslim donors</cite> as it is <cite id="8">zakat-eligible</cite> and specifically serves <cite id="1">underserved Muslim and minority populations</cite> in India.
alignment.improvement: IMRC could <cite id="1">expand services to additional regions</cite> with limited nonprofit coverage to further its mission of serving the most marginalized.

credibility.explanation: Donors can trust IMRC due to its <cite id="1">45-year track record</cite> and a <cite id="2">100% independent board</cite> consisting of 14 members. It maintains <cite id="1">strong transparency in its financial reporting</cite> via Form 990 filings.
credibility.improvement: To strengthen credibility further, the charity could <cite id="1">seek external evaluations</cite> to provide independent verification of its program outcomes.

impact.explanation: IMRC operates with a <cite id="2">89.8% program expense ratio</cite> and a direct service model that <cite id="5">supported over 16,000 students</cite> in 2021. Its <cite id="2">high working capital</cite> ensures program continuity.
impact.improvement: Impact measurement would benefit from <cite id="1">tracking and reporting beneficiary counts</cite> more consistently to enable detailed cost-per-beneficiary analysis.

donor_fit_matrix.evidence_rigor: Grade C - Output tracking via annual reports

grantmaking_profile.grant_strategy: Direct service delivery through local operations

rich_narrative.headline: Indian Muslim Relief and Charities provides comprehensive humanitarian aid and social empowerment to India's marginalized minority communities.

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who want to support the long-term resilience of Muslim minorities in India through a financially stable, zakat-eligible institution.
donor_motivations: Want to fulfill zakat obligations for the most needy in India
Value financial stability and massive cash reserves in a charity
Prefer organizations with extremely low fundraising overhead
Care about multi-sectoral aid (health, education, and food)
giving_considerations: The charity has a declining revenue trend that may require more active donor support
Impact is reported in outputs (meals, patients) rather than long-term social change metrics
Focus is exclusively on India and its minority communities
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking high-growth startups or those who require rigorous academic RCT evidence before giving.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: Grade C reflects consistent tracking of output metrics (e.g., <cite id="5">183,100 patients treated</cite>) without external validation of long-term outcomes.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: IMRC aims to alleviate poverty and achieve equality for Indian minorities by providing essential services in education, health, and emergency relief.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Evidence ensures that large-scale distributions of food and medicine are effectively improving the quality of life for beneficiaries.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: Despite large reserves, the <cite id="1">declining revenue trend</cite> and massive humanitarian needs in India suggest a high capacity for additional funding.

peer_comparison.differentiator: IMRC stands out for its <cite id="2">extraordinary fundraising efficiency ($0.01 cost)</cite> and its <cite id="2">massive operating reserves</cite> compared to peers.

similar_organizations.differentiator: Higher focus on modern fundraising and marketing
similar_organizations.name: Penny Appeal USA

strengths.detail: The organization demonstrates remarkable fiscal discipline, spending only <cite id="2">$0.01 per $1 raised</cite>, which is significantly lower than industry averages.
IMRC delivers large-scale relief, including <cite id="4">supporting 10,000 students</cite> and providing <cite id="4">water access to 587,000 people</cite> in a single year.
With <cite id="2">55.7 months of working capital</cite>, the charity has an 'endowment-style' reserve that protects its programs from short-term funding fluctuations.

strengths_deep_dive: IMRC's operational strength lies in its ability to scale direct services across a vast geographic area. Its healthcare program is particularly robust, having <cite id="5">treated 183,100 patients in 2021</cite>, while its feeding programs reached a peak of <cite id="4">16.4 million meals provided in 2020</cite>. This scale is supported by a <cite id="2">100% independent board of directors</cite>, ensuring high standards of governance and oversight for its <cite id="1">$48.7 million in total assets</cite>.
rich_narrative.summary: Indian Muslim Relief and Charities (IMRC) is a humanitarian organization <cite id="1">founded in 1981</cite> to support India's marginalized Muslim and minority communities. The organization operates a wide range of social empowerment programs, including <cite id="3">education, healthcare, clean water, and emergency relief</cite>. In 2023, IMRC reported <cite id="1">total revenue of $13,833,809</cite>, primarily driven by <cite id="1">$13.39 million in public contributions</cite>. The charity maintains a highly efficient financial model, spending <cite id="2">$0.01 to raise every $1</cite> in donations. Its impact is significant; in 2021 alone, the organization <cite id="5">provided 7.2 million meals</cite> and <cite id="5">treated 183,100 patients</cite> through its healthcare initiatives. IMRC is <cite id="8">verified as zakat-eligible</cite>, allowing Muslim donors to fulfill their religious obligations through programs that serve the <cite id="1">fuqara (poor) and masakin (needy)</cite> across various Indian states, including <cite id="1">Jammu and Kashmir</cite>. Despite a <cite id="1">3-year revenue CAGR of -10.2%</cite>, the organization remains financially robust with <cite id="2">55.7 months of operating reserves</cite>, ensuring long-term stability for its direct service delivery model.
